III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4127
Section Staff to resident ratio
Description (4) When residents are asleep or otherwise outside of the direct
supervision of staff, staff shall perform variable interval, eye-on
checks of residents. The time between the variable interval checks
shall not exceed fifteen minutes.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Staff did not complete interval checks on a youth prior to the youth
AWOL’ing.
Investigation Interviews:
Supervisor 1 was interviewed face to face at the facility on
September 19, 2025. Supervisor 1 reported he was notified by
staff during the morning meeting huddle on September 8, 2025,
that Youth A was missing from the home for several hours over
night. He reported if a youth is to leave the home without
permission and is deemed to be AWOL, staff are to notify the on-
call supervisor right away, which he reported did not occur in this
situation. Supervisor 1 reported he reviewed the video footage of
the incident on September 7, 2025. He reported he watched Youth
A go out on the front porch of the facility around 9pm and then left
at 9:20pm. Supervisor 1 reported there was no footage showing
staff actually checked on Youth A on the porch which was not in
compliance with their supervision policy. He reported Staff 1 and
Staff 2 were the second shift staff working with Youth A that day
and Staff 3 was the overnight staff working. Supervisor 1 reported
due to the concerns of lack of supervision and not reporting this
incident all three staff are no longer employed at the facility.
Staff 1 was interviewed via phone on September 22, 2025.
Staff 1 reported on September 7 he was working second shift with
Staff 2. He reported Staff 2 does not typically work one on one
with the youth as she does more of the medical appointment
coordination but due to staffing issues Staff 2 worked that night.
Staff 1 reported from 2pm to 7:45pm he was in charge of
documenting the fifteen-minute checks. He reported these checks
are to only be done when the youth are within their bedroom. Staff
1 reported if a youth is on the porch or downstairs, it is best
practice to try to be with the youth but if unable, to know where
they are. He reported if youth are downstairs, in the living room, or
2

outside and staff are not directly with them, staff do not need to be
documenting the fifteen-minute checks on them. This consultant
confirmed with Staff 1 the checks are to be done every fifteen
minutes or at random intervals and Staff 1 reported he was trained
it is every fifteen minutes. Staff 1 reported after he was done doing
her checks at 7:45pm he handed it over to Staff 2 to take over. He
reported he went on to do medication passing. Staff 1 reported he
gave Youth A his medication around 8:50pm and that was the last
time he saw him. He reported Staff 2 was in charge doing the
checks at this point and he was unaware of Youth A even going
on the porch. Staff 1 reported he left his shift around 10:20pm that
night and thought Youth A had been in his room as Staff 2 stated
everyone was accounted for. He was unaware that Youth A had
AWOL’d that night and did not find out until he was contacted by
Director the following day. Staff 1 reported he was very frustrated
because he verified before he left for the night with Staff 2 that
everyone was accounted for. He reported he has heard from other
people that some staff do not do the checks on the youth, which
he believes now Staff 2 never completed any checks. He reported
he has heard from other workers that their facility lacks when it
comes to the fifteen-minute checks and he feels that there needs
to be more oversight by the supervisors at the facility. Staff 1
reported he also feels there needs to be better training and follow-
up with staff post training because he felt they do a lot of video
training that do not give that real life experience. He reported he
feels there needs to be follow up from supervisors on making sure
everyone is doing their job correctly and understands how to do
their jobs.
Staff 2 was interviewed via phone on September 22, 2025.
Staff 2 reported she does not typically work as a direct care staff
with the youth as her role at the facility is to more coordinate
medical appointments. She reported she has been trained as a
direct care staff but does not know all the policies and protocols as
that is not her typical job. Staff 2 reported she was called in to
work the second shift on September 7, 2025, as the facility
needed additional staff to be within ratio. She reported Staff 1 was
in charge of completing the fifteen-minute checks on the youth.
Staff 2 reported earlier in the shift, two other youth had left the
facility without permission, so she was making sure those two
youth did not leave again. She denied ever doing any physical
checks but made sure the two youth did not leave their room. Staff
2 denied ever documenting anything on paper or in the computer
for checks to be completed. When asked more to explain the
requirements for these checks, Staff 2 confirmed when a youth is
in their bedroom then fifteen-minute checks need to be completed.
3

She reported she was trained by other staff that you do not need
to open the door and look at the youth and to document they are
still in their room every fifteen minutes. Staff 2 reported at the end
of the night she saw on the paperwork that staff are supposed to
physically see the youth in their rooms, but she stated that does
not happen with staff. She also confirmed the staff are not trained
that it needs to be variable intervals, just every fifteen minutes.
Staff 2 reported she was unaware if these checks were only for
when the youth are in their bedroom or if they are out of line of
sight of staff. She reported she has witnessed staff pull up the
camera footage to see what the youth are doing in the basement
and outside, they don’t physically always check on the youth. Staff
2 reported she knew that Youth A was outside later on that
evening but thought he had come back into his room. She
reported she did not know if there were any rules about youth
being outside and what the supervision looks like. Staff 2 reported
she was unaware that he went AWOL from the facility around
9:20pm and was only notified the next day by staff.
Staff 3 was interviewed via phone on September 23, 2025.
Staff 3 reported he came into work third shift at 11pm on
September 7, 2025. He reported when he arrived Staff 2 was the
only staff there. Staff 3 reported he had asked Staff 2 how the shift
went, and she reported that it went well overall. He reported Staff
2 told him there were two youths that had gone AWOL over the
shift, and she had called on-call supervisor about this. Staff 3
reported Staff 2 then left the facility, and he began to do room
checks. He reported when he checked Youth A’s room, he noticed
he was not in his room, and he assumed Youth A was one of the
youth that Staff 2 was talking about that had gone AWOL. Staff 3
reported Staff 2 never told the names of the youth that went
AWOL. He reported Youth A returned back to the facility around
1:50am. Staff 3 reported he completes room checks every fifteen
minutes over night and he actually opens the doors to look at the
youth in their room. He reported it can be variable intervals to do
checks, but he does them every fifteen minutes. Staff 3 reported
that he has come onto shift and noticed that there have been
multiple times where second shift staff have never documented
their checks.
Video Recording
Video record of September 7, 2025 during the time of
08:57pm to 9:23pm was reviewed by this consultant. This
video footage is captured outside of the home in the front area.
Youth A walked out the front door to sit at the patio at 8:58pm and
there was no staff with him. At 9:02pm, another youth from the
4

program comes out the door to talk with Youth A outside for about
a minute. At 9:07pm, another youth from the program comes out
the door to talk with Youth A outside for about ten minutes. At
9:17pm, Youth A is again fully alone outside. At 9:23pm, Youth A
walked out of the camera view towards the road of the building.
There was no staff seen checking on Youth A while he was
outside the home within this video review.
Documents Reviewed:
- Facility Incident Report dated 09/08/2025 completed by
Supervisor 1- This incident report notes on 09/08/2025 at
7am Staff 4 was notified by Staff 3 that Youth A had gone
AWOL for 3 hours overnight. Staff 4 had reported this
information to Supervisor 1 on the morning of 09/08/2025.
Supervisor 1 completed a video review of the incident
where Youth A was sitting on the front porch of the facility
at 9pm on 09/07/2025. Youth A began walking away from
the facility at 09:23pm. Youth A did not return back to the
facility until 1:52 am on 09/08/2025.
- Email from Director to Licensing Consultant dated
09/08/2025- Email from Director to Licensing Consultant
explained in detail more about Youth A’s AWOL that
occurred on 09/07/2025. Director reported to Licensing
Consultant, “Yes, when a youth is on the porch and outside
of direct staff supervision, staff are still expected to
complete eyes-on checks at variable intervals not to
exceed 15 minutes, in accordance with supervision
protocols.”
- Facility’s Staff to Resident Ratio Policy last updated
8/3/2023- This policy notes, “when residents are asleep or
otherwise outside of the direct supervision of staff, staff
shall perform variable interval, eye-on checks of residents.
The time between the variable interval checks shall not
exceed 15 minutes.”
- Email from Director dated September 24, 2025- Director
reported they only have the observation log that Staff 3
completed the night of 09/07/2025. She reported she was
unable to locate the observation log that should have been
completed by Staff 1 and Staff 2 during second shift of
09/07/2025.
5

- Facility Observation Log dated 09/07/2025 from
11:10pm to 09/08/2025 6:34am- This facility observation
log was completed by Staff 3. He started his checks at
11:10pm which noted all youth were in their rooms, except
Youth A. He reported at the 2:01am check all youth were in
their rooms and did not say Youth A was still gone. Staff 3’s
bedroom checks were noted to be completed at 11:10pm,
11:30pm, 11:50pm, 12:00am, 12:15am, 12:30am, 12:45am,
1:00am, 1:15am, 1:32am, 1:47am, 2:01am, 2:16am,
2:30am, 2:45am, 3:01am, 3:15am, 3:30am, 3:45am,
4:00am, 4:15am, 4:30am, 4:47am, 5:01am, 5:15am,
5:45am, 6:01a,. 6:16am, and 6:34am. These checks do not
fall within the timeframes required by licensing as some of
them are not variable intervals as they were every fifteen
minutes and some of them were over the fifteen minute
mark.
- Human Resource File for Staff 1- Staff 1 had been
working at the facility since October 2024. He has no noted
disciplinary actions within her HR file prior to this incident.
Staff 1 was up to date on all required training and most
recently completed the supervision requirements training
on 02/28/2025.
- Human Resource File for Staff 2- Staff 2 had been
working at the facility since April 2023. She has no noted
disciplinary actions within her HR file prior to this incident.
Staff 2 was up to date on all required training and most
recently completed the supervision requirements training
on 12/02/2024.
- Human Resource File for Staff 3- Staff 3 had been
working at the facility since May 2020. He had two prior
previous performance coaching plans due to in May 2022
he was not completing bed checks within the intervals not
to exceed fifteen minutes and for not following the facility’s
code of conduct. Staff 3 was up to date on all required
training and most recently completed the supervision
requirements training on 11/28/2024.
- Facility internal investigation report- The facility’s
Human Resource department completed an internal
investigation report of the concerns of these allegations
between 09/10/2025- 09/12/2025. Within the findings it
6

noted the following about the three staff: “Staff 1 on
09/7/2025 violated the State of Michigan Licensing Policy
and Employee Misconduct policy when falsifying
documentation by agreeing with 15- minute checks were
complete on a specific client when the checks had not been
completed. Staff 1 placed the client at risk by not knowing
where the client was after 9:30pm and did not create an
Emergency Incident Report-AWOL alert as required. Staff
2 on 09/07/2025 violated the State of Michigan Licensing
Policy and Employee Misconduct policy when falsifying
documentation by agreeing with 15- minute checks were
complete on a specific client when the checks had not been
completed. Staff 2 placed the client in a risk scenario by not
knowing whereabouts and did not create an Emergency
Incident Report- AWOL alert as required. Staff 3 on
09/08/2025 violated ORR reporting process when he failed
to place an Emergency Incident Reported into Orr’s case
management system within four hours of knowledge of the
incident. Furthermore, when Staff 3 was required to
participate in an internal investigation, he became evasive
and sarcastic telling the investigator multiple to go and
investigate the video system himself, violating the
Employee Misconduct Policy.” Staff 1, Staff 2, and Staff 3
all had separations of employment on 09/15/2025.
Analysis The facility was found in non-compliance of staff completing eye-
on interval checks on youth when they are not in direct
supervision of staff. This was found to be evident as within the
interviews with staff and video review, no staff completed an eyes-
on check on Youth A when he was sitting on the porch and staff
were unaware, he left the home. It was also found within the
observation check log, Staff 3 was completing bedroom checks on
youth that were either exceeding fifteen minutes or being
completed every fifteen minutes.
Technical Assistance
Within interviews with staff, it appeared they were unaware of
exactly what the policy was for checking in on youth. There were
concerns noted from the interviews that staff only have to do a
check every fifteen minutes, staff do not need to fully go into a
youth’s bedroom to check on them when sleeping, and that staff
can watch the cameras when the youth are outside or downstairs
as their check ins. Staff also provided feedback that needs to be
7

more supervisory oversight and check ins with staff. Staff also
reported that there needs to be more in-person trainings rather
than only computer-based trainings. This consultant recommends
for there to be increased supervisory oversite and more in-person
trainings, especially as it pertains to policies and procedures.
Conclusion Repeat Violation Established
09/18/2025 Renewal, CAP Approved 09/19/2025
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4150
Section Incident reporting
Description (3) If an institution determines that a youth is absent without legal
permission, then the institution shall immediately report the
information to law enforcement, the parent/legal guardian or next
of kin, the licensing authority, and the referring agency.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation Facility did not report to licensing authority or law enforcement in
an immediate base time frame of Youth A being deemed AWOL.
Investigation Interviews:
Supervisor 1 was interviewed face to face at the facility on
September 19, 2025. Supervisor 1 reported Staff 1, Staff 2, or
Staff 3 never called the on-call supervisor or police when Youth A
was considered to be AWOL. He reported he did not report the
incident to Licensing Consultant immediately because he was not
aware of Youth A being AWOL until 09/08/2025 around 9am.
Supervisor 1 reported due to the concerns of this situation he
needed to figure out first what happened as Youth A was already
returned safely. He reported once he had the information he
needed that was when he reported it to Licensing Consultant.
Staff 1 was interviewed via phone on September 22, 2025.
Staff 1 reported he was unaware that Youth A had even AWOL’ed
from the facility during his shift on September 7, 2025. He
reported if he was aware she would have called the on-call
supervisor to be given directions on what next steps need to
taken. Staff 1 reported the on-call supervisor is the one to tell staff
when to call law enforcement to make a report. He reported she is
unaware of who reports the incident to state licensing but does not
believe that is the staff’s responsibility.
Staff 2 was interviewed via phone on September 22, 2025.
Staff 2 reported since she did not know that Youth A had left the
facility she did not call the on-call supervisor. She reported the
policy is if an incident occurs like a youth leaves the facility without
permission, staff are to call the on-call supervisor right away. Staff
2 reported the on-call supervisor then will tell staff what next steps
8

need to be taken, such as contacting the police or going out to
look for the youth. She reported she is unaware of who notifies
other people about an AWOL incident, such as state licensing.
Staff 2 reported she believes that is the job of the on-call
supervisor, but it did not occur during the incident because the
staff were unaware that Youth A was gone from the facility.
Staff 3 was interviewed via phone on September 23, 2025.
Staff 3 reported he did not call the on-call supervisor when he
noticed Youth A was not in his room because Staff 2 mentioned
she had already talked to on-call supervisor earlier that day. He
reported he assumed everything was already handled. Staff 3
reported the protocol is that if a youth leaves the home without
permission staff are to call the on-call supervisor immediately. He
reported the on-call supervisor tells staff what to do next. Staff 3
reported the on-call supervisor had given him direction before to
not call local law enforcement until two to four hours after the
youth left the facility. He reported he does not know who notifies
state licensing of the AWOLs.
Documents Reviewed:
- Facility Incident Report dated 09/08/2025 completed by
Supervisor 1- This incident report notes on 09/08/2025 at
7am Staff 4 was notified by Staff 3 that Youth A had gone
AWOL for 3 hours overnight. Staff 4 had reported this
information to Supervisor 1 on the morning of 09/08/2025.
Supervisor 1 completed a video review of the incident
where Youth A was sitting on the front porch of the facility
at 9pm on 09/07/2025. Youth A began walking away from
the facility at 09:23pm. Youth A did not return back to the
facility until 1:52 am on 09/08/2025. Within the report it
noted that Licensing Consultant was notified of the incident
on 09/08/2025 at 5:30pm. It was also noted there was no
report made to local law enforcement.
- Email from Supervisor 1 to Licensing Consultant dated
09/08/2025 at 3:06pm- Licensing Consultant was notified
of Youth A’s AWOL on 09/08/2025 at 3:06pm. Licensing
Consultant confirmed with this consultant that there were
no other emails sent or phone calls made to her of an
earlier report of Youth A going AWOL on 09/07/2025.
- Facility Incident Report Policy last updated 7/12/2021-
Within this policy it notes that Runaway (AWOL) is
considered to be an action where staff would complete a
incident report. The policy notes, “Upon an incident
9

occurring a Supervisor or On-Call staff must be consulted
immediately. The Supervisor or On call Staff will notify
State Licensing within 24 hours in following situations: a.
Any incident requiring inpatient hospitalization; b. Death of
a resident; c. Runaways (AWOL); d. Unauthorized Outings;
E. Law enforcement involvement (resulting from resident’s
behavior).”
- Facility Unauthorized Absences (AWOL Policy) dated
7/2/2025- The facility denies AWOL (Absent Without
Leave) to be when a child has left or is missing from the
facility without authorization. The facility to follow “the
immediate actions upon discover of AWOL: 1. Assess if
911 must be called. Call 911 if any of the following applies:
child has successfully absconded and is no longer on the
premises; the child is need of emergency medical or mental
health services; local or state licensing regulations require
it. 2. Immediately notify- State Licensing agency.”
- Human Resource File for Staff 1- Staff 1 had been
working at the facility since October 2024. He has no noted
disciplinary actions within her HR file prior to this incident.
Staff 1 was up to date on all required training and most
recently completed BCS significant Incident Reporting
training on 10/29/2024.
- Human Resource File for Staff 2- Staff 2 had been
working at the facility since April 2023. She has no noted
disciplinary actions within her HR file prior to this incident.
Staff 2 was up to date on all required training and most
recently completed BCS significant Incident Reporting
training on 12/02/2024.
- Human Resource File for Staff 3- Staff 3 had been
working at the facility since May 2020. He had two prior
previous performance coaching plans due to in May 2022
he was not completing bed checks within the intervals not
to exceed fifteen minutes and for not following the facility’s
code of conduct. Staff 3 was up to date on all required
training and most recently completed BCS significant
Incident Reporting training on 09/09/2024.
- Facility internal investigation report- The facility’s
Human Resource department completed an internal
investigation report of the concerns of these allegations
10

between 09/10/2025- 09/12/2025. Within the findings it
noted the following about the three staff: “Staff 1 on
09/7/2025 violated the State of Michigan Licensing Policy
and Employee Misconduct policy when falsifying
documentation by agreeing with 15- minute checks were
complete on a specific client when the checks had not been
completed. Staff 1 placed the client at risk by not knowing
where the client was after 9:30pm and did not create an
Emergency Incident Report-AWOL alert as required. Staff
2 on 09/07/2025 violated the State of Michigan Licensing
Policy and Employee Misconduct policy when falsifying
documentation by agreeing with 15- minute checks were
complete on a specific client when the checks had not been
completed. Staff 2 placed the client in a risk scenario by not
knowing whereabouts and did not create an Emergency
Incident Report- AWOL alert as required. Staff 3 on
09/08/2025 violated ORR reporting process when he failed
to place an Emergency Incident Reported into Orr’s case
management system within four hours of knowledge of the
incident. Furthermore, when Staff 3 was required to
participate in an internal investigation, he became evasive
and sarcastic telling the investigator multiple to go and
investigate the video system himself, violating the
Employee Misconduct Policy.” Staff 1, Staff 2, and Staff 3
all had separations of employment on 09/15/2025.
Analysis The facility is found in violation as there was never a report made
to law enforcement of the youth being AWOL. Staff 1 and Staff 2
were unaware that Youth A had gone AWOL but Staff 3 noted him
to be AWOL on his first bedroom check at 11:10pm. The facility
also did not notify the licensing authority immediately. Even
though there was miscommunication about Youth A being AWOL,
the leadership team was notified the morning of September 8,
2025, that Youth A had gone AWOL. Licensing Consultant was
notified of the AWOL until 3:00pm on September 8, 2025 that
Youth A had gone AWOL.
Technical Assistance
When reviewing the policies and procedures as it pertains to
incident reporting and AWOL policy, there is conflicting timeframe
reporting. Within the facility incident reporting policy, it notes the
supervisor on-call is to notify state licensing within 24 hours in the
following situation: a. Any incident requiring inpatient
11

hospitalization; b. Death of a resident; c. Runaways (AWOL); d.
Unauthorized Outings; E. Law enforcement involvement (resulting
from resident’s behavior). This does not follow the time frames
within the state licensing rule requirement for incident reporting.
This policy needs to be updated as it noted within the rule
requirements for 400.4150. The facility’s Unauthorized Absences
(AWOL Policy) notes that when a youth is discovered to be AWOL
that state licensing needs to be notified immediately, which is in
compliance with the rule but does not follow what it does in the
incident reporting policy. Both policies should be reviewed and
updated to be within compliance with reporting requirements per
state licensing rules. The staff should also be trained as what the
policy is as none of the staff were aware of who does the reporting
to state licensing. It was also concerning as staff noted they are to
call the on-call supervisor first before calling the local law
enforcement about the AWOL concern. Staff reported sometimes
the on-call supervisor has told them to wait a couple hours before
calling local law enforcement about the AWOL. This contradicts
with what the facility’s Unauthorized Absences (AWOL Policy)
states as it states 911 should be contacted immediately when a
youth has successfully absconded and is no longer on the
premises. The policy show be reviewed and made sure it notes
who is responsible for taking actions within this policy as staff all
noted within their interviews they are just trained to call on-call
supervisor and then follow what they tell them to do.
Conclusion Violation Established
12

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
